description: From Latin exstirpō (“uproot”), from ex- (“out of”) +‎ stirps (“the lower part of the trunk of a tree, including the roots; the stem, stalk”).

verbs.description: extirpate (third-person singular simple present extirpates, present participle extirpating, simple past and past participle extirpated)

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To clear an area of roots and stumps.
(transitive) To pull up by the roots; uproot.
(transitive) To destroy completely; to annihilate, to cause to go extinct locally.
examples: Synonyms: annihilate, destroy, eradicate, exterminate; see also Thesaurus:destroy
The cougar was extirpated across nearly all of its eastern North American range in the two centuries after European colonization.
